title-group.article-title: Where Do Home Buyers Pay Most for Relative Transit Accessibility? Hong Kong, Taipei and Kaohsiung Compared

author-notes.corresp: Oliver Shyr, Jamie Wang, Taiwei Huang and Olivia Liu are in the Department of Urban Planning, National Cheng Kung University, 1 University Road, Tainan, 701, Taiwan. Email: ofshyr@mail.ncku.edu.tw, jamies5403@yahoo.com.tw, k2004huang@hotmail.com and olivia1130@hotmail.com.

David Emanuel Andersson is in the Department of Economics and Quantitative Methods, University of Nottingham Ningbo, 199 Taikang East Road, Ningbo, Zhejiang, 315100, China. Email: David.Andersson@nottingham.edu.cn.

abstract.p: The three cities of Hong Kong, Taipei and Kaohsiung all feature state-of-the-art transit systems, but transit commuting rates are markedly different, ranging from less than 10 per cent in Kaohsiung to about 90 per cent in Hong Kong. This paper looks at the effect of transit station accessibility on housing prices in these three cities, which are all located on the south-eastern edge of the Greater China region. The key finding is that accessibility impacts stand in an inverse relationship to the size and popularity of the transit system. The results illustrate how intraregional variability in overall transit accessibility declines with increases in the spatial coverage of transit systems. The price premium for housing near transit stations is therefore greatest in Kaohsiung and smallest in Hong Kong, with Taipei exhibiting intermediate levels. Conversely, average land values are highest in Hong Kong and lowest in Kaohsiung.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As one of the most successful transit systems in the world, Hong Kong’s metropolitan transit railway (MTR) network attracts more than 6 million passengers each day. With over 1.3 million daily trips by metropolitan rapid transit (MRT) and a total of 2 million daily trips by MRT or other types of public transport, the Taipei metropolitan area also exhibits high rates of transit ridership. On the other hand, the Kaohsiung MRT, which was opened in 2008, attracts less than 150 000 daily trips or 7 per cent of total trips in the Kaohsiung metropolitan area (see Table 1). Figure 1 depicts the metropolitan transit railway (MTR) lines and the distribution of observed house transactions in Hong Kong, while Figures 2 and 3 do the same for the metropolitan rapid transit (MRT) lines in Taipei and Kaohsiung respectively. The maps convey the comprehensiveness of the Hong Kong and Taipei systems, as compared with the two lines that make up the entirety of the Kaohsiung MRT network. However, it is also evident that Hong Kong’s MTR is a network that covers virtually all residential areas throughout the metropolitan areas, whereas Taipei’s MRT accessibility is substantially lower in the region’s peripheral areas than in its more central locations. Indeed, neighbourhood and transit development have to a substantial extent been integrated into co-ordinated land use plans in Hong Kong, whereas in Taipei a transit network was superimposed on neighbourhoods that had developed long before the transit network was planned.

sec.p: Despite being similar in terms of sharing a common Chinese cultural heritage and high population densities, the daily transport habits of residents in the three cities present modal splits that differ as much as Paris does from Houston. This contrast demonstrates that public policy choices and priorities have a major impact on individuals’ daily transport choices.

Does accessibility to the transit network affect housing prices differently in these three cities? The specific question that is analysed in this paper is whether a city with a more popular transit system exhibits higher or lower price premiums associated with short distances to the nearest rapid transit station. The results of the analysis reveal that the transit accessibility price premium is greatest in Kaohsiung, which is the city with the least popular and least extensive transit system. On the other hand, Kaohsiung exhibits average land values that are much lower than those found in the other two cities.

The fact that the price premium is greatest in the region with the least developed and least popular transit system might seem counter-intuitive. There are nevertheless good economic reasons for this result: a maximally comprehensive transit system would imply that all housing units have immediate access to a transit station, which would imply that transit-related price differentials would disappear. Still, the superior accessibility associated with the network as a whole should be reflected in the overall competitiveness of the region, with higher land prices than less well-endowed regions.

Hedonic price estimation is used for estimating the implicit prices of various accessibility attributes, controlling for other relevant housing attributes. The observations of the dependent variable comprise actual transaction prices (as reported to the Ministry of the Interior) in Taipei and Kaohsiung and asking prices as advertised by real estate agents in Hong Kong. The independent variables consist of numerous structural, neighbourhood and accessibility attributes. Estimated functional forms include a log-linear specification, which measures average attribute elasticities, as well as the each-side Box–Cox-transformed form with one transformation parameter for the dependent variable (λ) and a separate transformation parameter (θ) for the set of independent variables.

sec.title: Hedonic Prices
sec.p: Hedonic price theory is associated with the introduction of the term in a paper by Sherwin Rosen (1974), using ideas that had already been pioneered by a number of economists in the 1960s (see for example, Lancaster, 1966). Rosen uses a utility-maximising approach to derive implicit attribute prices for multi-attribute goods under conditions of perfect competition, where each attribute has a unique implicit price in equilibrium. Perfect competition, however, rests on assumptions of perfect information, which is not normally approximated in markets for housing or other real estate markets.

Perfect competition is, however, not a necessary assumption for empirical hedonic price studies. Barzel (1989) approaches multi-attribute goods in a more dynamic way, by building on the insights of property rights theorists such as Demsetz (1967). Webster and Lai (2003) extend Barzel’s theory to spatial economics in a way that explicitly takes dynamic processes and imperfect information into account. From such a dynamic standpoint, empirical hedonic price models do not produce stable estimates of equilibrium prices, but rather snapshots of transitional conditions. For example, a discovery of two centres with separate large-area distance gradients in the same urban region does not necessarily invalidate the common monocentric assumption; it could be a transitional stage where a declining and an emerging centre both impact the willingness to pay of market participants for a finite time-period—a reflection of asymmetric and imperfect information among buyers and sellers.

In general, hedonic price models aim at disentangling the attributes of a good from one another for the purpose of estimating implicit prices. In housing models, the price or rent is a function of various attributes, typically divided into structural and location attributes. Location attributes can be further sub-divided into general accessibility and localised neighbourhood effects.

Regression techniques make it possible to estimate the implicit price for each attribute. Linear models are usually avoided, since the assumption of constant marginal implicit prices is untenable unless there are constant returns to scale in production or costless repackaging of two or more bundles. The most common non-linear models include log-linear, semi-log and Box–Cox-transformed functions. The log-linear and semi-log functions are pre-specified functions, while Box–Cox functions use an iterative procedure that maximises the log-likelihood of the function within a pre-specified family of functions. Such maximisation ensures a more desirable distribution of the error term than with less flexible estimation techniques.

In this study, we use both the log-linear functional form and the separate each-side version of the Box–Cox function. Both functional forms are compatible with the underlying economic theory and relatively simple, and the Box–Cox function includes most common functional forms as special cases. The log-linear function has the interpretative advantage that the estimated coefficients correspond to average attribute elasticities. All pre-specified functional forms—including the log-linear function—have the advantage of allowing direct comparisons of quantitative attribute effects across markets. On the other hand, it is often advisable to compare the results of different functional forms in order to identify non-robust estimates. For this reason, we also estimate each-side Box–Cox functions for all three cities.

sec.title: Transit Accessibility and House Prices
sec.p: There are many studies of the effects of accessibility on housing development which include analyses of local and regional transit networks. Among them, Cervero (1994) found that, for San Francisco Bay Area cities served by Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART), residents living near transit stations were around five times as likely to commute by rail transit as the average gainfully employed resident in the same city. He concluded that the strongest predictors of whether station-area residents commuted by rail were whether their destinations were near transit stations and whether they could park for free at their home transit station. Moreover, neighbourhood density and proximity of housing to stations were also related to transit use. Cervero (1994) suggests that, if transit-based housing is to reap significant mobility and environmental benefits, it must be accompanied by transit-based employment growth and programmes that pass on additional costs to motorists.

Armstrong and Rodriguez (2006) analyse a slightly more extensive rail network than in most hedonic studies. They estimated accessibility benefits of rail services in eastern Massachusetts, including multimodal accessibility to commuter rail stations and distance from the rail right-of-way. The results were inconclusive, except that proximity to commuter rail right-of-way produced a significant negative effect on property values, which probably reflects negative externalities such as noise.

Bowes and Ihlanfeldt (2001) suggest that railroad station accessibility should affect property values since such access reduces commuting costs. This should help to attract retail activity from localities further away from stations, other things being equal. Possibly countering these positive effects are negative externalities such as noise and better access for criminals. Their results—from Georgia in the US—suggest that stations that are located sufficiently far away from the urban core tend to attract new residential development.

The most comprehensive studies of rail networks have been conducted in the Netherlands in a number of theoretical and empirical studies by Debrezion, Pels and Rietveld (for example, 2006a, 2006b). Unlike other authors, they have adopted a multiregional perspective that extends to the Netherlands as a whole. Debrezion et al. (2006a) use a hedonic pricing model to analyse the impact of the railroad network on house prices in the Netherlands. They use several access variables, including station accessibility, train service frequency and track proximity. Among other findings, they estimated that housing in close proximity to railroad stations commands market prices that are about 25 per cent more expensive than equivalent housing at a distance of 15 km or more. A problem with their approach is that they analysed the Netherlands as a whole rather than just the Randstad conurbation; the use of several spatially segmented markets in the same hedonic price function is associated with biased estimates of attribute effects (Palmquist, 1991).

Hedonic studies from Taiwan on the interconnectivity of high-speed rail and local transit networks show that proximity to high-speed rail (HSR) stations is associated with substantial price premiums, but only if the HSR station is located near important production nodes and is integrated within a comprehensive local transit network (Andersson et al., 2010; Andersson et al., 2012).

With sufficiently good information flows, improved accessibility will be capitalised in land values in conjunction with the initial investment decision. The normal case is, however, imperfectly informed markets, due to uncertainties regarding the credibility of decisions as well as future impacts of investments on the economy as a whole. The overall effect is therefore likely to be gradually incorporated into house prices, with distinct price effects that correspond to the sequence of relevant events: station location decisions; the commencement of construction; the opening of the line; and the cumulative experience from consuming transport services. The first three effects should have been fully incorporated in the land value observations in all the three cities that we analyse in this paper, while the service experience component should have been fully capitalised in land values in Hong Kong and Taipei, but only partially in Kaohsiung, since the Kaohsiung MRT system had only been in existence for less than one year during the period that is analysed in this study.

Yiu and Wong (2005) studied such a temporal sequence in their analysis of the land price effects from a proposed tunnel project in Hong Kong. Their results show that expectations of improved accessibility had been capitalised in house prices to a substantial extent well before the completion of the tunnel. They suggest that such expectation effects may enable governments to fund infrastructure investments by selling land in areas with contingent accessibility benefits.

sec.title: The Data
sec.p: The residential sales observations in Taipei and Kaohsiung refer to sales consummated in 2008 and are actual transaction prices. These prices and the structural attributes associated with each dwelling were obtained from the Department of Land Administration of Taiwan’s government. In contrast, the house price and structural attribute data from Hong Kong were collected from several real estate agents. Unlike Taipei and Kaohsiung, the observations are limited to the third and fourth quarters of 2008.

Observations of neighbourhood education levels in the Taipei and Kaohsiung areas were obtained from the Ministry of Finance. In Hong Kong, the Census and Statistics Department of the Special Administrative Region (SAR) government provides education, income and immigration statistics by district. In all three metropolitan areas, the neighbourhoods correspond to officially designated districts in either the core areas (Taipei and Kaohsiung) or the entire investigated area (Hong Kong). Suburban areas beyond the city boundary are divided into townships in the two Taiwanese regions. District income statistics are not available for districts in Taipei or Kaohsiung, but the correlations between education and income in Taiwan’s suburban townships as well as in Hong Kong’s districts suggest that the effect of spatial income variability is largely captured by the effect of spatial educational variability (the correlation coefficients between the percentage of neighbourhood residents with a college degree and the mean neighbourhood income were in all cases greater than 0.9). In Hong Kong, two measures of the proportion of district residents with foreign citizenship are also included, since foreign and mainland Chinese citizens make up a much larger share of the population in Hong Kong than in Taiwan. Foreign citizens are divided into rich-country (mostly North America, Europe and Japan) and poor-country citizens. ‘Poor-country citizens’ include Hong Kong residents with mainland Chinese passports.

The neighbourhood attributes ‘commercial zone’ and ‘residential zone’ refer to zoning regulations in Taiwan or Hong Kong, which are more flexible than in many other jurisdictions. All three cities have retained a mixed-use character since ‘residential zones’ allow commercial use on the first and second floors of many apartment houses and townhouses. ‘Commercial zones’ often allow for some residential use on higher floors. For example, downtown residential zones are typically used for high-rise apartment blocks with high-value commercial use such as banks and luxury retailing on the first two floors. In Taiwan (but not in Hong Kong), land use regulations tend to be somewhat haphazardly enforced compared with European or North American cities (Bernstein, 2007).

The transit accessibility variable is the distance in metres to the nearest MRT or MTR station. The average distance to the nearest MRT/MTR station ranges from 1.6 km in Hong Kong to 3.8 km in Kaohsiung, which shows that the average household accessibility gains that are associated with investments in rapid transit have been greater in Hong Kong than in Kaohsiung (with Taipei being closer to Hong Kong than to Kaohsiung). Other accessibility attributes that the hedonic price function controls for include distance to the relevant HSR station (Taipei and Kaohsiung), distance to the international airport (all three cities) and—most importantly—distance to the central business district (all three cities). The distance data for Taipei and Kaohsiung correspond to the shortest route for motor vehicles according to a popular GIS programme that covers the entire road network of Taiwan (PaPaGo R12). In Hong Kong, distance measurements correspond to minimal road distances according to Google Maps.

sec.title: Estimation Results
sec.p: The hedonic analysis makes use of sales prices rather than rents, which implies that expectations of future property-specific accessibility conditions will be reflected in the price. Sales prices should therefore—unlike rents—reflect potential long-term future benefits of new or planned infrastructure investments.

We use two alternative approaches when selecting the set of independent variables to be included in the hedonic price function. In the first approach, we use only those variables that are available in each of the three cities. In addition, we use a fixed-effect specification of neighbourhood effects, whereby each neighbourhood is assigned a separate dummy variable. This approach is used in order to ensure the comparability of the transit accessibility results across all three metropolitan areas. The second approach is to use all available variables, which differ somewhat between Hong Kong and the two cities in Taiwan. This second approach results in more detailed results, but strict comparability only applies to Taipei and Kaohsiung (which share the same set of independent variables).

sec.p: Most of the structural and accessibility attributes are statistically significant and have the expected signs in the six hedonic price functions (see Tables 5 and 6), while the detailed functions (see Table 6) show that the same is true of the various neighbourhood attributes. The apparent exception is that airport accessibility is associated with a negative price effect in Hong Kong and Kaohsiung, but with a positive one in Taipei. This is not as strange as it seems. The included airports in Hong Kong and Kaohsiung are both in peripheral special-purpose locations, while Taipei’s included airport (Songshan Airport) is located in one of the most accessible neighbourhoods in central Taipei.

In the fixed-effect hedonic price functions (Table 5), we see that the distance to the nearest transit station has a significant effect on house prices in all three cities. It is, however, also clear that this effect is much less pronounced in Hong Kong than in Taipei or Kaohsiung. The estimated transit-distance elasticities range from −0.027 in Hong Kong to −0.069 in Taipei and −0.071 in Kaohsiung. While the estimated coefficients in the Box–Cox functions cannot be compared in an equally straightforward manner, it is nevertheless clear that the results are similar and that the price effect is much smaller in Hong Kong than in either Taipei or Kaohsiung. While all Box–Cox functions are closer to a log-linear than a linear function, they are significantly different from a log-linear function in both Hong Kong and Taipei. In contrast, the estimated transformation parameters are similar to (and not significantly different from) a log-linear function in the case of Kaohsiung.

In the fixed-effect function, the transit distance elasticities are very similar in Taipei and Kaohsiung. However, for these two cities, there are a number of additional housing attributes for which observations are available in both cities. The hedonic price functions that result from including additional structural, neighbourhood and accessibility attributes are shown in Table 6. While the Hong Kong results are in this case not entirely comparable with the results from Taipei and Kaohsiung, it remains the case that Hong Kong exhibits the smallest price effects associated with transit station accessibility. More interestingly, it now becomes possible to separate the estimated effects in Taipei from those in Kaohsiung: the estimated attribute elasticity for the distance-to-MRT attribute is −0.044 in Taipei, while it is −0.072 in Kaohsiung. Thus, the city with the least comprehensive network is associated with the highest market valuation of network access.

The most plausible explanation for these findings is that the general transit network in Hong Kong is the most comprehensive one. Not only is the MTR network unusually extensive, there is also a well-developed system of feeder and express buses that present viable public transport options to those residents who happen to live in locations with (relatively) low MTR accessibility. And since residential areas cluster around MTR stations in Hong Kong (see Figure 1), it is also the case that the necessity to connect with a bus is not associated with the type of time/distance handicaps that can be expected to be associated with bus transport (as compared with rapid transit) in a city where the population is more dispersed. In comparison, good MRT access is associated with a core-city location in Taipei (see Figure 2), while in Kaohsiung only a small subset of origin–destination pairs benefit from radical time/distance reductions as compared with the situation before the opening of the transit network (see Figure 3).

Table 7 shows the marginal transit accessibility price estimates at a distance of 1 km from the nearest transit station. The other variables are fixed at their region-specific mean levels. This price is highest in Kaohsiung, followed by Taipei and Hong Kong, which reverses the order associated with economic development indicators such as the mean land price per square metre or the regional per capita income.

sec.p: While the establishment of the transit system may have had the general effect of raising Hong Kong’s attractiveness, accessibility and thus land prices, it is likely that it is truly general in an intraregional sense as well: benefits have been widely dispersed rather than concentrated along favoured transport corridors.

It should in this context be noted that Hong Kong has the world’s highest rate of public transport use. The daily numbers of MTR trips and bus trips amount to 0.52 and 0.58 trips per person respectively. These are extremely high average trip frequencies. By comparison, the corresponding rates in Taipei are 0.20 (MRT) and 0.26 (bus), while in the Kaohsiung metropolitan area they are as low as 0.04 (MRT) and 0.02 (bus) (see Table 1). Overall, use of public transport in Taipei resembles several large European cities, while residents in Kaohsiung use public transport about as seldom as residents in the average American metro region. Kaohsiung’s low rate of MRT use (i.e. 0.04 trips per day corresponding to 7 per cent of all metropolitan area commuting) is surprisingly low when one considers that Kaohsiung’s population density exceeds 2700 inhabitants per square km, which is higher than the average of European or North American metropolitan regions.

Taipei represents an intermediate case, which is also reflected in the fact that about half of all home-to-work commuting is by public transport. Thus, estimated implicit MRT accessibility prices fall between the corresponding estimates for Hong Kong and Kaohsiung. Taipei has a much more comprehensive transit network than Kaohsiung, but service frequencies and bus networks have not yet reached the omnipresence that is so characteristic of Hong Kong.

sec.title: Final Remarks
sec.p: According to the results of the hedonic analyses, we conclude that the transit distance elasticity ranged from -0.016 in Hong Kong to -0.044 in Taipei and -0.072 in Kaohsiung. The hedonic results imply that the distance to the CBD (i.e. Central on Hong Kong Island) is by far the most important accessibility attribute of any housing unit in Hong Kong. In Taipei or Kaohsiung, the accessibility of a house is not as one-dimensional; the distance to the nearest MRT station is an important secondary accessibility consideration. Indeed, the results show that, while the distance-to-CBD gradient is between 10 and 12 times steeper than the distance-to-MRT gradient in Hong Kong, this multiple is only 2.1 in Taipei and 2.0 in Kaohsiung. (Note that, based on the results, we can conclude that the Central Station rather than Taipei 101 is the accessibility-maximising centre among the nodes included in the hedonic price function for Taipei; see Table 6.) In other words, the location of residences vis-à-vis MRT stations matters to home buyers in Taipei and Kaohsiung, while it is at most a minor consideration in Hong Kong, despite a much greater reliance on public transport among Hong Kong residents. Put differently, one may say that the feasibility of transit-based commuting depends on one’s location in cities with less developed transit systems, while such commuting is feasible in all parts of a city with a comprehensive transit network.

There is also a more general implication of the results from these three cities. It is that cities with a truly comprehensive transit network are similar to cities without any network in one crucial respect: there will be no intraregional accessibility differences that arise from differential access to public transport services. Conversely, accessibility to transit nodes becomes most important as a consideration for buyers (or renters) of real estate in cities where the transit network is concentrated along a few corridors with vastly superior accessibility to both the urban core and parts of its hinterland.
